moves.1. d4: I had white pieces and started with d4.
moves.3. Nc3: Nc3, white is trying to get the pawn back.
moves.3... Nf6: Nf6 is a very sensible move, develops the knight and defend the pawn.
moves.4... exf3: exf3, black wants to maintain the material advantage.
moves.5. Qxf3: normally white would capture with knight, Qxf3 leaves the d4 pawn unprotected, but white is actually setting up the trap, d4 pawn is the bait.
moves.5... Qxd4: my friend was a bit greedy and took the bait.
moves.6. Be3: Be3 develops the dsb, also attacks black queen.
moves.6... Qb4: Qd8 looks embarrassing, but that would be a better move than the move played in the game, which is Qb4, attacks the b2 pawn. it seems like white can't castle queen side, because O-O-O results in Bg4, skewers the queen and the rook on d1.
moves.7... Bg4: Here comes the skewer! is white in trouble now, maybe my friend thought I would resign after this move.
moves.8. Nb5: Nb5 was played! Did white commit suicide? Not really! Can you see black's problem? if black captures the queen, then Nxc7# !
moves.8... e6: Black actually saw the problem, and played e6, now Nxc7 won't be mate.
moves.9... Qe4: my friend realized he was in trouble, Qe4, protects the rook on a8, also hopes queen exchange.
moves.10. Nxc7+: No thanks, no queen exchange for you my friend, Nxc7+
moves.11... Kd8: Kd8, now there is mate in two
moves.13. Qc8#: Here is mate! At move 11, black can play Kd6, but Qc6 would be checkmate. Halosar trap worked! That's all about this game, hope you like it, thank you!
